comments.text:
+Kyermemehtar
The word "Electrocution" literally means "Death from electric shock".  
Nonlethal Electrocution is an oxymoron.  Stun-Guns and Tasers deliver an 
electric shock to stun the target, they don't electrocute (unless something 
has gone horribly wrong and the target dies as a result of being shocked).  
Given your context, Hanks question probably should have been "why don't 
they shock themselves?"
comments.author: damage.cc

comments.text:
Electrocution doesn't necessarily kill. That's why weapons like stun guns 
and tasers are considered "non-lethal". The voltage generated by the eel is 
only enough to stun small fish and not enough to seriously harm the eel 
itself.
comments.author: Kyermemehtar

top_comment.text: arent platypus's.. amphibians because they swim and stuff?﻿
top_comment.author: Wholickedme

comments.text:
+MegaMementoMori
Good explanation! Except you mean class, not kingdom. :)

Also, it's not that hard to outsmart Linnaeus. The man did *very* well for 
his time, but much of his taxonomy is outdated today (and he did much more 
thorough work on plants than he did animals). Mind you, I say this as 
someone who works at a Linnaeus museum and has a lot of respect for him as 
a scientist and thinker.
comments.author: Life Happens

comments.text:
Systematics doesn't actually care about what you look like or behave like, 
only what your ancestors were. We can *recognize* different groups by some 
simple superficial characteristics - most mammals have fur, for example - 
but whales are still mammals by definition, because even though they lack 
fur, they share a common ancestry with animals who do (we call this a 
*monophyletic* group).

This is also why we don't call any legless lizard a snake - no matter how 
snakey it looks, snakes are an exclusive taxonomic club, membership of 
which can only be inherited. :)

... Of course, this gets very complicated when some members of a group 
evolve that are so different that we want to put them in a parallel 
category. For example, because reptiles, birds and mammals (including the 
platypus!) all evolved from amphibians, systematically speaking they *ARE* 
amphibians. You're an amphibian! (And a fish, for that matter!) But that 
doesn't seem very helpful, does it?

This is where we get *paraphyletic* groups, which exclude a few lineages 
that are descended from them. Class Amphibia is a paraphyletic group, 
because most of the time when we say "amphibian" we mean "amphibians except 
reptiles, mammals and birds".

Paraphyletic groups are rarely used in formal systematics, but in daily 
speech we use them all the time because it just gets unbearable otherwise. 
For completeness' sake, there are also *polyphyletic* groups, members of 
which look the same but are unrelated (typically because they have a body 
shape that is universally useful and has evolved many times in different 
groups). Polyphyletic terms include "worm" and "tree".


tl;dr: Yes, a platypus is technically an amphibian, but not for the reasons 
you suggested, and not in a way that anyone except a systematic biologist 
cares about. :D
comments.author: Life Happens

have hollow bones. Nothing lies outside these kingdoms (except for the

common ancestors, if a mammal suddenly decided to breathe in water by a 
gill-like organ, if would not be a fish, but it would start it's own small 
kingdom.

comments.author: GeneralPeewee

comments.text:
In psychology that is called sensory adaptation.
By constantly being stimulated by the same amount of a stimulus, our brains 
actively desensitizes us. And when some change occurs suddenly, that would 
then be noticed again.

For example, turning on a fan, at first you'd notice the fan's sound, but 
after hearing that sound for sometimes you just find yourself ignoring it. 
Same goes to the feeling of the wind blowing on you. And if the fan turns 
off suddenly, you'd notice the room is quieter and you'd stop feeling the 
wind again.

In layman's term, you just get used to it.
comments.author: C Leo

comments.text:
The thing is, evolution is fueled by natural selection; a beneficial 
mutation that helps a species survive will become more common as that 
mutation is passed down. This isn't a thing that just happened a while ago 
and has stopped, it's still happening today. So, if two species that are 
similar but not linked by a common ancestor would still both benefit from 
being electroreceptive or having electrogeniesis, that mutation will 
eventually propagate throughout the species.

comments.author: DeathLordFhyeg

comments.text:
+SilentBudgie That is the classic mistake in reasoning concerning ID: If it 
was designed then it should be so and so... ergo, bad design. We don't know 
what it looked like when it was first designed and made. In cases of 'bad 
design', from an ID perspective we look at possible degeneration. If you 
assume evolution you would approach it from the other direction and 
conclude that a proposed creator was sloppy/dumb/irresponsible or something 
like that. Basically, the interpretation is backed by a belief. If you 
believe one thing, the other idea sounds dumb. We need to think outside the 
box, so to speak.
comments.author: Andre van Gelder

comments.text:
+Andre van Gelder If we assume that everything in biology has a purpose 
rather than being an adaptation to environment, that raises more questions 
than it answers. For example, the legs and feet of land mammals have a bone 
structure that works well for walking, but bats and dolphins have modified 
versions of the same bone structure in their wings and flippers. That bone 
structure is not the most efficient way to make a wing or flipper, so if 
bats and dolphins were designed, then apparently the designer felt that it 
was more important to make all mammals look like they evolved from each 
other than to make animals good at what they do.
comments.author: SilentBudgie

comments.text:
+SilentBudgie I was being sarcastic. Sorry for the confusion ;-) by the 
way, medical treatment doesn't get better based on 'knowledge' of 
evolution. It is based on experimentation and hard work. The advancement of 
science can do well without belief in a spontaneous generation and unguided 
advancement of life. I would even argue that science would be better off 
with the starting assumption that biological systems were designed with a 
purpose and therefore have or had an important function, which needs to be 
repaired if malfunctioning or removed if totally broken. Research could be 
conducted on the purpose of each living system and what its original 
function was or what it is supposed to be doing...
comments.author: Andre van Gelder

comments.text:
+DeathLordFhyeg From what planet are you? There are many scientists that at 
least have an inclination to the possibility of a designer...
comments.author: Andre van Gelder

comments.text:
+Andre van Gelder
Those aren't difficult words. If just the names of major fields of study 
like "ecology" and "microbiology" seem difficult to you, then I understand 
why you are having problems with the content of those fields.

This isn't a fallacy of generalization. Those studies have already been 
reviewed, confirmed, and interpreted. The interpretations of the 
overwhelming majority of all life science research for the last century 
points to evolution.

Proposing a different hypothesis at this point is like proposing a 
different hypothesis for electricity. True, no one has literally seen an 
electron flowing through a wire, but while skeptics can argue for a 
different explanation of electricity, the rest of us will use the existing 
theory to built better machines. Similarly, while some people try to fit 
the evidence of evolution into their pet hypothesis, the rest of us will 
use medical treatment based on what we know about evolution.
comments.author: SilentBudgie

comments.text:
+Andre van Gelder 
Out of all the scientific research and data gathered in any fiekd of 
natural science, *0% of it can be interpreted as "a designer did it"*. 
Saying that only goes to show that you really dont understand science and 
you most probably have no formal or informal training or knowledge in it.
comments.author: DeathLordFhyeg

comments.text:
+SilentBudgie Wow, you must have done a lot of research to put all those 
difficult words into one sentence... You know this is the fallacy of gross 
generalization, don't you? All the findings in all these scientific 
branches have to be interpreted. Now there are several ways to interpret 
them, but generally speaking (since we are already doing that, as it seems) 
there are two main world views. Everything 'did' itself or some designer 
did it. If you generally rule out a designer, then there is nothing left 
but to think that everything just 'happened'. I am generally convinced 
there is a Designer and that designer must be the God of the Bible. I am 
not saying this to start another discussion, just so you know what I think. 
All I was trying to say here is that I find it very unlikely that some 
trait just 'happened' 11 times independently ... I am not trying to prove 
anything, just putting some thoughts down into words. And I do appreciate 
all the feedback :-)
comments.author: Andre van Gelder

top_comment.text:
I'm sorry but we are done.

Is this really what SciShow has come to? Top # lists and trashy attention 
grabbing headlines?

If the last 3 months are any indication, it won't be long before we start 
seeing videos with titles like "Top 10 ways science improves celebrity 
weddings!" or "5 scientifically guaranteed positions to make him/her want 
another 'cram' session!".

If this is the direction you Want to go with your channel, then go for it. 
I'm not going to step on anyone's dreams. But I certainly will not be 
coming along for the ride.

Neither will my money.

I just cancled my SciShow subscriptions for YouTube and Subable. Thank you 
for the interesting science news over the years but if SciShow is not going 
to be a show that concentrates on Science, I'll spend my time elsewhere. I 
hope I check back in a while to find that you have come back to your roots. 
Until then.

Good day.﻿
top_comment.author: Overwatch

comments.text:
+woodfur00 Have you not noticed that a few months back they changed from 
reporting on NEW science, and talking about actual science, to making short 
videos with factoids and trivia? Here are examples...

Horseshoe Crabs Saved My Life
3 Reasons Mosquitoes Suck
Why Do Stars Twinkle?
Do Women Have Adam's Apples?
Top 10 New Species...
Huge Sperm and Giant Tentacles...
Milk, and the Mutants That Love It
...The 9 Greatest Minds of 2014

Those are literally just the ones that show up in the sidebar. There are 
dozens more.j

I'm not claiming that there isn't some actual science talk somewhere in 
there amongst the PopSci Shock reporting. I'm just looking back at my 
watching history and noticing that I am skipping 9 of their videos for 
every 1 I watch.

I funded them because they were educators who made science entertaining, 
not because they were entertainers who scraped together a few overly 
sensationalized facts to feed the masses.

I'm sure there are some that feel differently than me, and if you are among 
them, great! However, I don't feel the need to justify my decision in a 
series of replies. If SciShow wants more feedback from me they know where 
to reach me. Otherwise, I wish them the best on whatever path they choose.
comments.author: Overwatch

There is evolution, an opening up of, within a species, this why finches 
have so many different beaks. But in the end they are still finches and 
ultimately birds! 
Species reproduce after themselves, any mutation within a cell has been and 
will be detrimental usually causing death or practically harmless. BUT 
never any mutation recorded has been so extreme to classify another 
species. Anything including MACROEVOLUTION makes sense when you peer at it 
through subjective goggles.﻿

top_comment.author: Justin Gabriel

comments.text:
No, I don't think there's any chance that such fine-detail structures could 
be preserved in an animal fossil. Really the only way you can *begin* to 
answer a question like this is to do phylogenetic analysis using the 
genetic mechanisms involved across many different species.
comments.author: Life Happens

comments.text:
+Life Happens my best guess would probably be that originally some species 
of fish had cells sensitive to electromagnetic pulses and it later allowed 
them to find food in harsh habitats. If these fishes date back before the 
Permian extinction it's plausible but I doubt whether an animal is 
sensitive to this or not will have evidence in the fossil record. 
Electro-magnetic sensitive cells won't last in the fossil record, would it?
comments.author: Justin Gabriel

comments.text:
I was wondering about this too, actually. I'd be very interested to see if 
anyone's done any work on figuring it out.

My best guess - given that such many species have electroception, but only 
a few have electrogeneration - is that electroception evolved first, some 
fish were able to improve their senses by amping up their own electric 
fields and detecting disturbances in that, and finally some fish took that 
and weaponized it. But there are a few steps missing there.

comments.text:
Voltage doesn't kill you. The current is what kills you. The resistance in 
the human body is more or less unchanging, but if you were to change it, it 
would necessitate more electric potential to cause the same current that 
would kill you.
comments.author: Menea6587

comments.author: pykapuka

comments.text:
+Randygandalf95
not lying entirely... where there's voltage there's current, it just 
depends on the resistance. if you have 450 volts and no resistance current 
is essentially unlimited. fortunately the human body has a fair amount of 
resistance, considering how much water is in the body, and can take upwards 
of 10,000 volts with little harm. That's about the charge on a fairly 
powerful static shock, abut the same to jump 1 cm through air.

+LeoMRogers

not in this case.

comments.author: Brendan Bohannon

comments.text: +Brendan Bohannon Have you ever attempted a double blind test?
comments.author: LeoMRogers

comments.text:
+Brendan Bohannon This is true, yeah. Pressure is such a complex sensation 
biologically, so I would agree on that. It's probably most of what you 
would feel in situations of small electromagnetic fields, as opposed to 
pain. It still isn't the same as the fish senses, but I'd agree with you 
that I stand corrected about it being entirely nociception.
comments.author: Leafie the Great

comments.text:
+actuatedgear

yeah, though curiously (in the case of magnets), it feels like a slight 
pressure away from the magnet, rather than a pull towards it.
comments.author: Brendan Bohannon

comments.text:
+Leafie the Great

I suspect it is more closely related to "pressure" for low-intensity cases, 
like close proximity to AC leads to slight pressure vibrations in the skin 
or similar, which can be felt (at short distances) if one pays attention.

it is in this sense sort of like noticing heat shimmers to see that an 
object is hot. heat shimmers are subtle and easily missed if one doesn't 
pay much attention.


pain/itch + randomized hot/cold spikes seem to be what generally occurs 
with direct electrical contact. it is much more obvious with 9V or higher 
(more so one ones tongue), but still seems noticeable down to around 1V (as 
a very slight pain-like sensation, and with some experience one can use the 
level of pain to determine the approximate amount of voltage present).

so, in this sense, it seems it is possible to determine whether or not 
batteries are dead without needing to pull out a volt-meter.


though, granted, it does seem to build on top of other senses.

like, the same basic physical sensation also often indicates when making 
contact with something which will likely cause contact-dermatitis or 
similar (ex: metal allergies, ...).
comments.author: Brendan Bohannon

comments.text:
+Brendan Bohannon Most of our sensation of electrical fields is related to 
nociception, or the sensation/perception of pain.

While we're certainly aware of being shocked, or of the buzzing in an 
electric fence, we don't detect it when electricity is introduced to the 
body of water we're standing next to. We don't know if there is an 
electrical circuit being made with the metal of our car when a power line 
falls on it. 

Our perception of electrical fields is very limited by the receptors we 
have for understanding our environment in this way, and it is not the same 
perception that some of these fish would have. We simply don't have the 
same receptors and associated neural structures to make it work.
comments.author: Leafie the Great

comments.text:
Well...There is iron in your blood. If you could detect the minute 
disturbance to movement or pressure  caused in your blood, you could feel 
the effect.
comments.author: actuatedgear

comments.text:
+Brendan Bohannon  Did you know you can amplify that feeling of electric 
current.  Simple as touching a socket with a bit of metal.
comments.author: luckynbr13

comments.text:
I suspect I can very slightly feel electric fields without using magnets 
(from 110VAC sources at close-distances), where it feels like a slight 
buzzing (very low intensity though).

more so if holding on to the drop-line from the power-lines, where the 
buzzing is stronger and ones' arm starts to go slightly numb after a little 
while (many seconds).

I can also slightly feel strong magnets (as a slight physical 
pressure/vibration) when waving my hand over them (generally for things 
like rare-earth magnets and similar).


I have thus far not noticed any adverse effects though, apart from stuff 
feeling weird/"oddly still" during blackouts.

not sure of any real physiological basis, but "something" would seem to 
exist.


low-voltage DC currents can also be felt if ones' skin is slightly wet and 
one closes the circuit (makes contact with both electrodes). a traditional 
example is putting a 9V battery on ones' tongue (such as, as a quick/lazy 
way to determine charge, but I can also use fingers), but it works in my 
case even with AA and AAA batteries (though it is a fair bit weaker than a 
9V, and is near the lower-end of what can be perceived).

note: big warnings apply here with UPS or car batteries, they are on a 
whole different level (despite being only 12V, they have large amounts of 
amps, and 12V on ones' skin can still be fairly painful IME, more so if 
skin is wet...).

or such...

comments.text: +Michael Hawthorne You Fell Like Responding To That?
comments.author: Eric Lin

comments.text:
All major words in a title are capitalized. No, it is not optional; it is a 
rule in the English language. The only words that are not capitalized are 
articles, and prepositions that are less than 5 letters long unless it is 
the first or last word in the title like in "Of Mice and Men".  
Rules:

1) Capitalize the first and the last word.
2) Capitalize nouns, pronouns, adjectives, verbs, adverbs, and subordinate 
conjunctions.
3) Lowercase articles (a, an, the), coordinating conjunctions, and 
prepositions.
4) Lowercase the "to" in an infinitive (I want to play guitar).
     Paraphrased from The Chicago Manual of Style: 16 ed. paragraph 8.155
comments.author: Grey Matter

captions.text: [Intro]

Hank Green: What you're about to see in this
SciShow Dose may shock you. There are about

8600 animals in the world that are electroreceptive.
They can feel electric fields. Like the sense

of touch, eletroreceptivity carries information
about the shape, size, and texture of things

in the environment, and like hearing or vision,
it works at a distance, but what it actually

feels like is something that we will never
be able to even imagine.

For electroreceptive animals, electric currents
and electric fields are as real and immediate

as color or music are for us. Most electroreceptive
animals are amphibians or fish, though there

are rare exceptions, including the duck-billed
platypus, because everything that could possibly

be weird about the platypus is weird. Electroreceptivity
has evolved over and over again, totally independently,

in a global act of convergent evolution. Animals
that live and hunt in murky water where they

might not be able to see or hear very well
gain advantage if they can feel their surroundings

through special electroreceptive cells in
their skin. And a few animals take it even

further. There are 716 known species of fish
capable of electrogenesis, the creation of

electric fields and even strong electric shocks.
And these fish don't have a common ancestor

either. Biologists believe that electrogenesis
has evolved separately at least 11 different

times in places as isolated from each other
as the African interior, the Amazon basin,
and the coral-rich waters of Australia.

The most famous electric fish is the electric
eel, which is electric but is not an eel--it's

actually a kind of knifefish that lives in
South America and can produce an electric

shock up to 600 volts--enough to hurt, but
not seriously injure, something as big as

a human, but if you're an itty bitty tiny
fish trying to go about your daily business

of swimming and eating and not dying, yeah,
600 volts is the last problem you'll ever
have.

All cells in living things produce an electric
charge; it's a normal part of cell biology.

They do this by pumping positive ions of metals
like sodium, potassium, and calcium outside

the cell membrane. So the outside of your
cells are slightly positive compared to the

insides. Every cell in your body has a resting
voltage of about 0.085 volts. Of course, my

cells aren't organized in a way that would
let me add those voltages together, but this

fish have special cells called electrocytes,
they're stacked in long chains like the batteries

inside a flashlight. And each one of those
cells is connected on one side to a nerve

fiber. When an electric eel charges up, its
brain sends a signal down those nerve fibers.

When the signal hits the electrocytes, little
pores open up in their cell membranes, allowing

those positive ions to rush into the cell.
Each cell becomes like a little tiny battery.

Instead of having a negative inside and a
positive outside, the cell now has a negative

left side and a positive right side. And just
like in a battery, electrons flow between

the two ends to equalize the charge. Since
the cells are stacked in chains, positive

to negative to positive and so on, the voltage
of each cell adds up with every other cell

in the chain. String enough of those chains
together and fire them all at once, and bleaughh,
underwater barbecue.

But this arrangement of electrocytes doesn't
have to be used offensively, and in most electric

fish, it isn't. Instead, they create a constant
electric field around themselves, usually

with the power of only a few millivolts. They
use this to sense their immediate environments

so they know when food or predators are nearby,
even in total darkness. And some species of

fish use these electric fields to like, communicate
with each other. Using distinct patterns of

discharges, they can signal aggression, submission,
alarm, even courtship. When they're ready

to mate, the males and females of many kinds
of electric fish will perform electric duets.
Electric boogie!

So if you feel like you're missing out, you
might be wondering, why didn't we evolve to

create awesome electric fields that we can
control with our minds? Well, because we can

see and hear. Seeing and hearing may seem
kind of boring compared to being like, electric

fish Magneto, but they use a lot less energy
than electrogenesis. Plus, one of the most

common questions people ask about electric
eels is 'why don't they electrocute themselves?'

The answer being that they do. When an electric
eel fires, you can actually see it flinch.

I don't know about you, but I think I'll stick
with my senses since they don't actually cause
physical pain to use.

Thanks for watching this electrifying SciShow
Dose, and if you'd like to help us keep sharing

natural wonders like this, go to Subbable.com/SciShow
to find out how you can help us keep our batteries

charged, and don't forget to go to YouTube.com/SciShow
and subscribe.
[Endscreen]

title: The Shocking Truth About Electric Animals!
